name: sweet corn production | sweet corn | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29900/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of Sweet Corn (fresh matter) in the US state of Washington at farm, with an at harvest moisture content of 76.%. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. Residues are not collected but remain on the field post-harvest and overwinter.;The average yield of Sweet Corn grown in Washington for the 2014-2021 seasons was 23,351 kg/ha (wet mass) (USDA NASS (2022a)). The dataset reflects the average Sweet Corn produced in Washington from 2014 to 2021, inclusive, as that period allows for at least one value from USDA statistics for most parameters and generally three or more.  Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices. (0% no till, 0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage) (EPA 2022; IPM center 2003; IPM center 1997 data) and being grown in rotations with other vegetable crops. While genetically engineered sweet (fresh) corn seed is available, the share of sweet (fresh) corn grown from genetically engineered seed is not compiled; it is estimated that between 75 and 90% of North American sweet corn is conventional (USDA 2018b).;Area, productivity, use of mineral and organic fertilisers and pesticides, and irrigation inputs are based on farmer data reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture where possible or budgets available for the state, unless otherwise noted. Field operations and equipment types and fuel use are based on materials provided to growers by the agricultural extension office(s), including farm budgets, and on survey information agricultural extension office(s) collect from growers, in conjunction with row spacing data from USDA.  59.6% of crop land has installed drainage (tile or ditch), based on state-level agricultural survey data from USDA.  Irrigation is included based on share of crop irrigated (86.6% over the time period, USDA NASS (2018d)).;Total cropland land use, for all crops, in Washington decreased by 4% between 1997 and 2017 (NRCS 2020); USDA NASS does not report cropped area for Sweet Corn prior to 2016. The ecoinvent practice and associated crop LCI tool allocate land use change to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years in the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase; crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits. Thus, the amount of Land use change, annual crop is close to zero for Sweet Corn grown in Washington.;Soil characteristics, including pH, are based on distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. In the absence of detailed direct soil pH data, the state-level share of soils in a particular pH band (that is, with a pH between its boundaries) is approximated as the share of the total test samples in that pH band. To test this assumption, the reported median soil pH is compared to the estimated average value using the approximated pH bins. Based on the agreement between the 2020 median pH and the approximated average soil pH for 2020, an approximate standard deviation is calculated using the variation in median values for 2020, 2015, 2010, and 2005 and the delta between the 2020 reported median and the approximate 2020 value. No anti-erosion practices are assumed in the dataset; instead, the erosion soil loss reported in the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's Natural Resource Inventory is used.;References:;USDA NASS (2022a) Area, Production, Yield by State - Sweet Corn - 2016-2022. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC);USDA NASS (2018b) Statistical Methodology Name of Survey: Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Phase II: PeanutProduction Practices Report, CornProduction Practices Report, and SoybeanProduction Practices Cost Report. US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Surveys/Guide_to_NASS_Surveys/Chemical_Use/2018_Peanuts_Soybeans_Corn/Statistical%20Methodology%202018.pdf;IPM center (1997) Crop Profile for Corn (Sweet) in Maryland. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/MDcorn-sweet.pdf;IPM center (2003) Crop Profile for Sweet Corn in the North Central United States. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center.Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/us-ncr-sweetcorn.pdf;EPA (2022) Assessment of the Benefits of Atrazine and the Impacts of Potential Mitigation for Field Corn, Sweet Corn, Sorghum, and Sugarcane; PC Code (080803). (MEMORANDUM).US Environmental Protection Agency. https://downloads.regulations.gov/EPA-HQ-OPP-2013-0266-1624/content.pdf;USDA NASS (2018d) 2018 Irrigation and Water Management Survey  (2017 Census of Agriculture).US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Online_Resources/Farm_and_Ranch_Irrigation_Survey/index.php;NRCS (2020) Land Cover/use of non-Federal rural land, by State and year, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. USDA, Natural Resources Conservation Service. http://www.nrcs.usda.gov/Internet/NRCS_RCA/reports/nri_crop_nat.html, https://www.nrcs.usda.gov/wps/portal/nrcs/rca/national/technical/nra/rca/text/#NRI%20Cropland;Bruulsema and Jones 2021. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. It ends with harvested sweet corn at the farm gate, prior to storage.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The valid period covers 2014-01-01 through 2021-12-31 based on primary data sources. The production volumes, areas and applications are covered by data throughout the time period (annual for production and area, alternate years for applications). Because the specific pesticides used show time-dependent trends, the most recent 2 years of data are used to avoid underweighting the most dominant pesticides currently used and to avoid skewing  impacts based on compounds no longer in use. Field operations are based on enterprise crop budgets and other guidance and change little year to year. The most recent enterprise budget available for Washington is from 2002, but operations included in it are consistent with more recent budgets and guidance from other states. The field operations are assumed valid through the dataset time period.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Production of Sweet Corn in Washington (US-WA).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset reflects current practice for Sweet Corn in Washington as of 2022.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Mineral fertiliser applications are crop and location (state and sub-state levels) specific for nutrient applied, based on survey data compiled by the USDA National Agricultural Statistics Service. Specific fertilisers are extrapolated from mineral fertiliser applications to  Specific fertilisers are extrapolated from mineral fertiliser applications to  Sweet Corn in Washington and market consumption in the US (IFA 2020). Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices.. The most recent enterprise budget available for Washington is from 2002, but operations included in it are consistent with more recent budgets and guidance from other states. The field operations are assumed valid through the dataset time period.  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Machine sizes (power) are approximate but based on common, recent surveys and equipment analyses (Lazarus 2020).  
 Emissions are calculated with standard methods according to ecoinvent documentation (Nemecek and Schnetzer, 2011. '01 crop production-direct field emissions natural resources' v1.2, August 2011, available at ) and the World Food LCA Database guidelines and the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. Soil characteristics, including pH and clay content, are extrapolated from  distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples.In the absence of detailed direct soil pH data, the state-level share of soils in a particular pH band (that is, with a pH between its boundaries) is approximated as the share of the total test samples in that pH band. To test this assumption, the reported median soil pH is compared to the estimated average value using the approximated pH bins. Based on the agreement between the 2020 median pH and the approximated average soil pH for 2020, an approximate standard deviation is calculated using the variation in median values for 2020, 2015, 2010, and 2005 and the delta between the 2020 reported median and the approximate 2020 value. Drainage tile data from 2012 (reported to USDA for the 2012 agricultural census) is extrapolated as valid from that date through the rest of the time period of the dataset and the distribution of drainage is treated as homogenous for all field crops. 
 Some pesticide quantities are extrapolated. Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). Farmers select one or more compounds specific to their conditions, regulations, cost, and pests identified, so the full list of pesticides are not applied in any single case. Where disclosing data would allow for identification of individual operations, pesticide data is withheld in the NASS database (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). This is the case for the overwhelming majority of pesticides applied to sweet corn. Where a state-specific and substance-specific value was available in NASS, that value was used (if a value was available for both 2018 and 2020, the average of the two was used). Because farmers select one or more compounds specific to their conditions, local regulations, cost, and pests identified, the full list of pesticides are not applied in any single case and approximations are used to account for the remaining pesticides. A quantity of total insecticides/herbicides/fungicides applied is sometimes available even when many of the substances in the category are reported with a “D”. If this total is available, the amount remaining after the sum of substance-specific values is accounted for is divided equally among the substances reported with a “D”. If the sum of available values exceeds or equals the total reported, any remaining “D” substances are treated as zero and omitted. If the total used in that state is not reported, the average sweet corn country-level value for each is used for the substances reported (“D” substances). If no average US sweet corn value for the substance is available, then the value applied for US maize is used to approximate the substance to avoid undercounting since pesticide use in sweet corn cultivation is universal or nearly so. In the event that not even a value for US maize is available, the substance is omitted. If all available data across all three categories for a state are “D”, as is the case for Florida, Integrated Pest Management guidance and crop profile summaries were used to identify substances and set approximate application amounts. 
 Transports are modelled with standard distances.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is obtained from state, county and national statistics, agricultural extension offices, and published literature. Data for production, yields, applications of NPKS fertilisers, applications of pesticides, row width, and irrigation (if any) was obtained from the US Dept of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service and in most cases provides high-quality data spanning the dataset time period. Field operations and energy use are from enterprise crop budgets provided by local agricultural extensions offices and their farmer survey data. Literature data is used where USDA and agricultural extension guidance and data are not available.

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.

6,074.1 m3/ha (2.6E-1 m3/kg Sweet Corn) irrigation. Water applied for irrigation  (7,010 m3/irrigated ha, 2018, 2020, USDA NASS 2018),  weighted by the share of acres irrigated  (86.6%, average over 2010-2018 from USDA NASS (2021);  percent of harvested irrigated acres not reported 2019-2021). 
Sources:
USDA NASS (2018d) 2018 Irrigation and Water Management Survey  (2017 Census of Agriculture).US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Online_Resources/Farm_and_Ranch_Irrigation_Survey/index.php

These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calcualted from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41. US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf.

Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.

Land occupation per year (annual growing season).  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021). US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it, thus the continuous flux to/from annual crop is effectively steady state. Annual production averaged  0.7  million tonnes from  2016-2021 on . million ha planted and . million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 0.428 ha/t or 4282.466 m2/t (0.4.282m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated ( 86.64% ) and non-irrigated ( 13.4% ) based on agricultural census data ( USDA NASS ) 3.71E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 5.72E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land

exchanges.description:
2.00 ha/ha (8.56E-5 ha/kg Sweet Corn) application of plant protection product, by airplane
Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). This is the case for almost all pesticide entries for sweet corn in Washington. Thus pesticide applications are based on the Washington Extension office enterprise crop budget  (2 ground herbicide and 2 aerial insecticide applications).  Application rates of specific pesticides are based on a Washington state profile (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002b) for sweet corn (compound) and Pacific NorthWest (Felix J 2022) integrated pest management materials (quantity). In the absence of data for acres treated the dataset assumes the guidance applies to all acres. Application by sprayer accounts for 50% (2.00 passes) and aircraft for 50% (2.00 passes).  An aerial pesticide application rate of 50% is used here.  
The National Agricultural Aviation Association estimates that approximately 28% of all US cropland (excluding range, pasture, and forest lands) is treated by aircraft annually (NAAA 2019, NAAA 2020).
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted.  (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002a, Hanna, Mark 2016, Schuler and Frank 1998, Lattz and Schnitkey 2021b).  Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices

exchanges.description:
0.061 ha/ha (2.63E-6 ha/kg Sweet Corn), calculated as the fraction of crop area treated with lime (30.7%, from soil grid level soil pH values and county level productivity, ISPAID8.1.1; USDA NASS) / (5  years between applications, based on Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011).
Lime is applied to all soils with pH below 6, and to high subsoil pH soils with pH between 6.5 and 6, based on expert guidance (J.E. Sawyer 2020). Cropped area needing liming is determined from grid level (sub-county level) data for soil pH and formation type (ISPAID8.1.1), weighted with county-level production data (NASS). The increase in pH with lime application remains dominant through at least 4 years from application (Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011).
Sources:

exchanges.description:
CO2 emissions from use of urea, fertilisers, and lime is 105.751 kg/ha (4.53E-3 kg/kg Sweet Corn): 62.5 kg/ha from lime and 43.25 kg/ha from urea and urea ammonium nitrate  (lime: 2.68E-3 kg/kg Sweet Corn; urea: 1.85E-3 kg/kg Sweet Corn). 
Emissions are calculated following the IPCC NIR Guidelines, §11.3 and §11.4, using IPCC NIR equations 11.12 (lime) and 11.13 (urea) (mass of lime/urea * emissions factor for lime/urea) with Tier 1 emissions factors (IPCC 2006b).  EF limestone = 0.12 kg CO2-C/kg limestone (0.06-0.12, uniform) and EF urea = 0.2 kg CO2-C/kg urea (0.1-0.2, uniform) applied to both urea and the approximately 35% of UAN that is urea. The result is converted from kg CO2-C to kg CO2 (multiplying by the molar mass of CO2/mass of C in CO2 = 44.01/12)

exchanges.description:
Each planted hectare uses 12.27 kg seed (5.26E-4 kg/kg Sweet Corn). This value is calculated from a seeding rate of 76,634 seeds/ha (Licht M, Parvej M R, Baum M 2019, 2020 Licht M) and an average seed count of 6,244 seeds/kg (averaged from commercial listings of F1 (SH2 and se-se) seeds, https://www.ufseeds.com/vegetables/corn/supersweet-sh2-corn, https://lacrosseseed.com/product-information/forage-tech-sheets/tech-sheets-alfalfa-5). While genetically engineered sweet (fresh) corn seed is available, the share of sweet (fresh) corn grown from genetically engineered seed is not compiled; it is estimated that between 75 and 90% of North American sweet corn is conventional (USDA 2018b). Seeding rates are based on state average guidance, not specifically for GE or conventional seed.  Germination and stand losses are accounted for in the seeding rate.The uncertainty parameters are calculated from the uncertainty on the range of seed sizes (seed counts per kg), the yield variation, and the variability in seed-to-stand ratios. Phosphate leaching to ground water 0.07 kg PO4/ha (2.998E-6 kg/kg Sweet Corn): 0.E+0 kg PO4/ha from manure and 7.E-2 kg PO4/ha from leaching from arable land.  Phosphate leaching to ground water is calculated using the SALCA-P model (Prasuhn 2006) with an average leaching factor for arable lands and the amount of phosphate in any applied manure, as implemented in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (see Ecoinvent_Too_Model_Description_20191015.pdf). Does not incorporate state or county data on soils, slope or conservation drainage infrastructure. Calculated with the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. If the slope is less than 3%, no phosphate loss through run-off occurs (Prasuhn 2006). If the slope is greater or equal to 3%, phosphate loss through run-off are computed like in (Prasuhn 2006) with the site-specific correction factors set to their default value (=1):

exchanges.description:
Application of limestone to raise soil pH, 303.87 kg/ha (1.3E-2 kg/kg Sweet Corn), calculated as the (mass of lime applied to treated acres (2 t/treated ha)) * fraction of crop area treated with lime (30.7%, from soil pH data from Bruulsema T and Jones J D 2021) / (5  years between applications, based on Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011). 
Lime is applied to all soils with pH below 6, and to high subsoil pH soils with pH between 6.5 and 6, based on expert guidance (J.E. Sawyer 2020). Cropped area needing liming is determined from grid level (sub-county level) data for soil pH and formation type (ISPAID8.1.1), weighted with county-level production data (NASS). The increase in pH with lime application remains dominant through at least 4 years from application (Mallarino A P, Pagani A, Sawyer J E 2011).
Sources:

exchanges.description:
1.00 ha/ha (4.28E-5 ha/kg Sweet Corn) fertilising, by broadcaster
Average application rates for mineral fertilisers (NPKS) on Sweet Corn in Washington are: 1.80 N applications on 99.0% of cropped area, 1.00 P applications on 56.0% of cropped area, 1.00 K applications on 6.0% of cropped area, and 1.20 S applications on 89.0% of cropped area (NPKS data from 2018). The budget includes pre-plant fertiliser application, ammendment with planting, and additional N delivered during the season via fertigation (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002a). Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other N, because they are applied differently, with different equipment Other than anhydrous ammonia, most NPK(S) fertilisers are applied together via broadcast application.
Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications (=0.43). Other N application is then total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia (=1.37). The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 23.65%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.42 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.43 * 99.0% of crop area with applied N) and 1.36 other N applications via broadcast (1.37 * 99.0%). Since the number of passes for N application after removing the anhydrous ammonia share is greater than the maximum number of passes reported for the other nutrients, this dataset assumes that any other fertiliser applications are reflected under that pass and the total fertiliser broadcast fertiliser passes are thus 1.36.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted.  (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002a, Hanna, Mark 2016, Schuler and Frank 1998, Lattz and Schnitkey 2021b).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s):

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.

Metolachlor emission to agricultural soil (1.656E+00 kg/ha).  Pesticides are assumed to be ultimately 100% emitted to soil across all rotation patterns, based on assumption that all sweet corn acres are treated, and assuming that cultivation is conventional tillage as common practice for weed management (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997).Data reported a quantity of total insecticides/herbicides/fungicides applied in sweet corn is sometimes available even when many of the substances in the category are reported with a “D”. If this total is available, the amount remaining after the sum of substance-specific values is accounted for is divided equally among the substances reported with a “D”. If the sum of available values exceeds or equals the total reported, any remaining “D” substances are treated as zero and omitted.  
Sources: SWEETCORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021,https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/#5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC,IPM center (1997) Crop Profile for Corn (Sweet) in Maryland. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/MDcorn-sweet.pdf,IPM center (2003) Crop Profile for Sweet Corn in the North Central United States. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center.Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/us-ncr-sweetcorn.pdf ,EPA (2022) Assessment of the Benefits of Atrazine and the Impacts of Potential Mitigation for Field Corn, Sweet Corn, Sorghum, and Sugarcane; PC Code (080803). (MEMORANDUM).US Environmental Protection Agency. https://downloads.regulations.gov/EPA-HQ-OPP-2013-0266-1624/content.pdf

Ammonia volatilised from applied mineral and organic fertilisers, 15.9 kg NH3/ha (6.79E-4kg NH3/kg Sweet Corn) total, 15.9 kg NH3/ha (6.79E-4 kg NH3/kg Sweet Corn) from synthetic fertilisers, 0.0 kg NH3/ha (0.E+0 kg NH3/kg Sweet Corn) from manure. .  NH3 from volatilisation of mineral fertilisers is calculated using Tier 2 emission factors (temperate climate, specific fertiliser) from the European Environment Agency, EMEP/EEA 3Da1, Table3.2 (EEA 2019). NH3 from manure application is calculated with emission factors provided in EMEP/EEA 3.D.a.2.a (Animal manure applied to soils) (EEA 2019) for manure types used as (fraction TAN in total N)*(EF manure spreading per TAN) for each animal group and type. (kg NH3-N/kg N applied: ). The emissions from manure calculated here do not account for the change in N mineralization and phosphate runoff with incorporation type or time. Where impacts from manure application are expected to be significant, this should be considered as N volatilisation during and after application of manure ranges from as low as 1% N with direct injection to ~5% with immediate incorporation to 20-40% without incorporation (Sawyer J, Mallarino A P (2016) Using Manure Nutrients for Crop Production. Cooperative Extension Service, Iowa State University of Science and Technology. https://store.extension.iastate.edu/product/12874and Midwast Plan Services MWPS-18, 3ed).
Sources: 
EEA (2019a) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook Part B: sectoral guidance chapters 3. Agriculture 3 D Crop production and agricultural soils. European Environment Agency. https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/4-agriculture/3-d-crop-production-and/view
EEA (2019b) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook Part B: sectoral guidance chapters 3. Agriculture 3 B Manure management. European Environment Agency. https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/4-agriculture/3-b-manure-management/view

4.28E-5 ha/kg stalk shredding (1. effective pass(es) per year). 
 The most recent enterprise budget available for Washington is from 2002, but operations included in it are consistent with more recent budgets and guidance from other states. The field operations are assumed valid through the dataset time period.
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices(0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage, and 0% no till).

exchanges.description:
The total nitrate leaching/runoff is 2.868E+2 kg NO3/ha (1.113E-2kg NO3/kg Sweet Corn), 2.000E+2 kg NO3/ha from fertilisers, 0.000E+0 kg NO3/ha from manure, 9.460E+1 kg NO3/ha from soil mineralization, and -7.858E+0 kg NO3 N uptake. 
9.4% is emitted to surface water and 90.6% to ground water, since 9.4% of cropland in Washington has drainage (ISU Extension 2020c).

exchanges.description: Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021). US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it, thus the continuous flux to/from annual crop is effectively steady state. Annual production averaged  0.7  million tonnes from  2016-2021 on . million ha planted and . million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 0.428 ha/t or 4282.466 m2/t (0.4.282m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated ( 86.64% ) and non-irrigated ( 13.4% ) based on agricultural census data ( USDA NASS ) 3.71E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 5.72E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land

This exchange is an aggregate of proxies for applied pesticide(s) Pendimethalin, Pyraclostrobin (1.422E+0 kg/ha {1,2,2,1,1}; 1.582E-1 kg/ha {1,2,2,1,1}, respectively).
Data reported a quantity of total insecticides/herbicides/fungicides applied in sweet corn is sometimes available even when many of the substances in the category are reported with a “D”. If this total is available, the amount remaining after the sum of substance-specific values is accounted for is divided equally among the substances reported with a “D”. If the sum of available values exceeds or equals the total reported, any remaining “D” substances are treated as zero and omitted. 
From SWEETCORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021, https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/#5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC

2.00 ha/ha (8.56E-5 ha/kg Sweet Corn) application of plant protection product, by sprayer
Pesticide data is sometimes withheld in the NASS database to avoid disclosing data for individual operations (denoted with "D" in the data returned for the query, indicating a non-zero but withheld value). This is the case for almost all pesticide entries for sweet corn in Washington. Thus pesticide applications are based on the Washington Extension office enterprise crop budget  (2 ground herbicide and 2 aerial insecticide applications).  Application rates of specific pesticides are based on a Washington state profile (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002b) for sweet corn (compound) and Pacific NorthWest (Felix J 2022) integrated pest management materials (quantity). In the absence of data for acres treated the dataset assumes the guidance applies to all acres. Application by sprayer accounts for 50% (2.00 passes) and aircraft for 50% (2.00 passes).  An aerial pesticide application rate of 50% is used here.  
The National Agricultural Aviation Association estimates that approximately 28% of all US cropland (excluding range, pasture, and forest lands) is treated by aircraft annually (NAAA 2019, NAAA 2020).
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted.  (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002a, Hanna, Mark 2016, Schuler and Frank 1998, Lattz and Schnitkey 2021b).  Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.

Land use change is allocated to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years for the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase. Crop production and natural land areas in all countries use data from 1989 to 2012 (FAOSTAT 2012), as well as for country climates and soil types (EU-JRC 2010c). Crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits.  Total cropland land use, for all crops, in Washington decreased by 4% between 1997 and 2017 (NRCS 2020a); USDA NASS does not report cropped area for Sweet Corn prior to 2016. 
Land use change (LUC) combines land transformation areas calculated with the adapted 'Direct Land Use Change Assessment Tool' version 2014 developed by Blonk Consultants and the carbon losses from soil organic carbon (SOC) and vegetation (VEG) as calculated in ecoinvent v3. See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports. Calculated value from ecoinvent Crop LCI tool, 0.15137 divided by the yield in kg/ha.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. exchanges.description:
1.00 ha/ha (4.28E-5 ha/kg Sweet Corn) fertilising, by injection
Average application rates for mineral fertilisers (NPKS) on Sweet Corn in Washington are: 1.80 N applications on 99.0% of cropped area, 1.00 P applications on 56.0% of cropped area, 1.00 K applications on 6.0% of cropped area, and 1.20 S applications on 89.0% of cropped area (NPKS data from 2018). The budget includes pre-plant fertiliser application, ammendment with planting, and additional N delivered during the season via fertigation (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002a). Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other N, because they are applied differently, with different equipment Other than anhydrous ammonia, most NPK(S) fertilisers are applied together via broadcast application.
Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications (=0.43). Other N application is then total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia (=1.37). The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 23.65%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.42 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.43 * 99.0% of crop area with applied N) and 1.36 other N applications via broadcast (1.37 * 99.0%). Since the number of passes for N application after removing the anhydrous ammonia share is greater than the maximum number of passes reported for the other nutrients, this dataset assumes that any other fertiliser applications are reflected under that pass and the total fertiliser broadcast fertiliser passes are thus 1.36.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted.  (Hinman H, Pelter G, Sorensen E and Fickle A 2002a, Hanna, Mark 2016, Schuler and Frank 1998, Lattz and Schnitkey 2021b).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.
Source(s): 
USDA NASS (2022d) Applications - fertilizers and pesticides - number, amount, - Sweet Corn- 2000-2021. exchanges.description:
6.85E-4 kg sulfur/kg Sweet Corn 
Quantities of specific fertiliser are calculated based on US fertiliser market share and nutrient compositions from IFA data to meet total nutrient demand N-P-K-S: 167.8--11.82--0.13--23.86 kg/ha  (USDA NASS data for 2018). Calculated from: average total N application (2018) reported cropped area of specified crop (includes all rotation patterns) and share of fertilisers in U.S. consumption mix (ecoinvent and IFA 2019) times each fertiliser's K2O to N ratio (IFA), subtracted from the application rate for the necessary nutrient, and multiplied by the mass of the compound over the mass of K2O in the compound. The remaining K2O and S demands are met from a mix of ammonium sulfate, potassium nitrate, potassium chloride, and potassium sulfate, the quantities of which are determined by satisfying the demand without adding any additional excess of any nutrient beyond that resulting from assuming the U.S. average mix of N fertilizers; any S demand remaining is met using elemental sulfur.
Sources: 
USDA NASS (2022c) SWEETCORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/#5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC; Ecoinvent U.S. consumption mix for N fertilisers, from IFA data; IFA (2021) Nutrient content in percentage - IFA Fertilizer Converter. International Fertilizer Association. https://www.ifastat.org/converter/fertilizer-converter/accessed 2021-06-24
